net.cloud.gfx.elements

Class AbstractButton

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.cloud.gfx.elements.AbstractElement
      • net.cloud.gfx.elements.AbstractButton
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Element, Focusable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Button, ImageButton, SelectableButton

    public abstract class AbstractButton
extends AbstractElement
    A generic base class for buttons elements. It has the code to take care of being clicked on, handling key events, and maintaining basic state information (whether the button has focus, is pressed down, or is just sitting there.) Subclasses must take care of drawing themselves, and can override various methods to grab events.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      private java.util.Optional<Element> deregisterTarget
      An element that will receive focus after the button is pressed, rather than deregistering to nothing

        y - Y-location

    • Method Detail

      • clicked

        public void clicked(Element clicked,
                    java.awt.Point relPoint,
                    boolean isRightClick)
        Overridden to do nothing. A mouse click will not make a general button gain focus, because then it just looks silly and feels a bit unintuitive. Could still key over to it, though.
        Specified by:
        clicked in interface Element
        Overrides:
        clicked in class AbstractElement
        Parameters:
        clicked - The element that was clicked. It may not be this element!
        relPoint - The point of click, relative to this element
        isRightClick - True if the right mouse button was clicked

      • pressed

        public void pressed(Element pressed,
                    java.awt.Point relPoint)
        When a button is pressed, it will request focus - even if only momentarily. (Rather than via a click) This is so that focus can be kept on a button that was pressed, conditionally, depending on the release.
        Specified by:
        pressed in interface Element
        Overrides:
        pressed in class AbstractElement
        Parameters:
        pressed - The element that was pressed. It may not be this element!
        relPoint - The point of click, relative to this element

      • released

        public void released(Element released,
                     java.awt.Point relPoint,
                     boolean onElement)
        When the mouse is released, for sure the button will no longer be pressed down. Regardless of release point. Also, if the button was already pressed down and the release is over the button, then that is what constitutes clicking the button. (Not the actual click event - which is more specific)
        Specified by:
        released in interface Element
        Overrides:
        released in class AbstractElement
        Parameters:
        released - The element that was released. It may not be this element!
        relPoint - The point of release, relative to this element. Invalid and null if the release is not on the element.
        onElement - True when the mouse release is over this element

      • keyTyped

        public void keyTyped(char key)
        Take care of button-specific key events, such as the action key being used to perform the button's action. Other events are allowed to propagate back to the superclass, such as focus traversal keys.
        Specified by:
        keyTyped in interface Element
        Specified by:
        keyTyped in interface Focusable
        Overrides:
        keyTyped in class AbstractElement
        Parameters:
        key - The character which was typed

      • actionPerformed

        protected abstract void actionPerformed()
        Called when an action has been performed on the button. Go figure. Essentially this means the button was pushed, selected, or acted on in some way.

      • setDeregisterTarget

        public void setDeregisterTarget(Element target)
        Set an Element to receive focus when this button would otherwise normally deregister focus. That is, when the button is pressed by the mouse, the focus will be registered to the target element. This can be provided null to remove the target.
        Parameters:
        target - The element to gain focus after the button is pressed
